articles.headline: Moving Forward in E-Readers
articles.snippet: Both Barnes & Noble and Kobo have introduced nearly identical e-readers that are clearly intended to embarrass the industry leader, the Amazon Kindle.
articles.abstract: Both Barnes & Noble and Kobo have introduced nearly identical e-readers that are clearly intended to embarrass the industry leader, the Amazon Kindle.
articles.lead_paragraph: We think we’re so modern. We think we’re hot stuff, with our touch-screen tablets, video cellphones and Internet movie downloads. But mark my words: we’re in the Paleozoic era of consumer technology.

articles.headline: In India, Dynamism Wrestles With Dysfunction
articles.snippet: In Gurgaon and elsewhere in India, economic growth is often the product of a private sector’s improvising to overcome government inadequacies.
articles.abstract: In Gurgaon and elsewhere in India, economic growth is often the product of a private sector’s improvising to overcome government inadequacies.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — In this city that barely existed two decades ago, there are 26 shopping malls, seven golf courses and luxury shops selling Chanel and Louis Vuitton. Mercedes-Benzes and BMWs shimmer in automobile showrooms. Apartment towers are sprouting like concrete weeds, and a futuristic commercial hub called Cyber City houses many of the world’s most respected corporations.

articles.headline: How I Learned to Stop Worrying by Loving the Smartphone
articles.snippet: A smartphone transformed the author from a ball of anxiety to a sunny, carefree person who is never without an answer.
articles.abstract: A smartphone transformed the author from a ball of anxiety to a sunny, carefree person who is never without an answer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN I think back to what I was like before the advent of the smartphone, I realize I must have been a quivering ball of anxiety.

articles.headline: Banks Defeated in Senate Vote on Debit Card Fees
articles.snippet: The Senate rejected a delay on regulations over debit card fees, essentially leaving it to the Federal Reserve to limit the fees that stores pay banks.
articles.abstract: The Senate rejected a delay on regulations over debit card fees, essentially leaving it to the Federal Reserve to limit the fees that stores pay banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate refused Wednesday to delay new rules that would sharply cut the fees that banks can charge retailers to process debit card transactions.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Falling Behind in the Business of ‘Green’
articles.snippet: Strong incentives in European and Asian countries have given them the lead in clean energy technologies.
articles.abstract: Strong incentives in European and Asian countries have given them the lead in clean energy technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — The Mark Group started hunting for a new untapped market when it realized that its core business — insulating old homes using innovative technology — would drop off in coming years. Based in this rust-belt city, the company had grown rapidly over the last decade largely because of generous and mandatory government subsidies for energy conservation that impelled the British to treat their homes.

articles.headline: With Smartphone Games, Downtime Becomes a Pastime
articles.snippet: Nearly everyone takes a phone with them, and almost all of those phones can run some decent games.
articles.abstract: Nearly everyone takes a phone with them, and almost all of those phones can run some decent games.
articles.lead_paragraph: All right, fess up, people. Have you never played a game on your cellphone? Really? I’m here to let you know you can come out of the closet now.

articles.headline: In Saudi Arabia, Royal Funds Buy Peace for Now
articles.snippet: This oil-rich kingdom is spending $130 billion to pump up salaries, build housing and finance religious organizations, effectively neutralizing any opposition.
articles.abstract: This oil-rich kingdom is spending $130 billion to pump up salaries, build housing and finance religious organizations, effectively neutralizing any opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As one nation after another has battled uprisings across the Arab world, the one major country spared is also its richest — Saudi Arabia, where a fresh infusion of money has so far bought order.

articles.headline: Too Radical a Debt Plan From Greece
articles.snippet: The Greek prime minister tried unsuccessfully to win support for a bond issue by Europe’s central bank to pay off his nation’s debts.
articles.abstract: The Greek prime minister tried unsuccessfully to win support for a bond issue by Europe’s central bank to pay off his nation’s debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In March, just as it was becoming clear that Greece might have to ask Europe for more money to prop up its failing economy, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou seriously considered a radical plan intended to resolve his country’s debt crisis once and for all.

articles.headline: Fearing Assault, More Syrians Flee Into Turkey
articles.snippet: Hundreds of residents fled across the border into Turkey, heightening fears of a refugee crisis and a widening crackdown.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of residents fled across the border into Turkey, heightening fears of a refugee crisis and a widening crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARBEYAZ, Turkey — Security forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria converged in the country’s restive northwest on Thursday as hundreds of residents fled across the border into Turkey, heightening fears of a budding refugee crisis and a widening crackdown on dissent.
articles.byline: By Sebnem Arsu and Liam Stack

articles.headline: Apple Gives Publishers a Sales Break
articles.snippet: Apple changed its guidelines for content subscriptions sold through its App Store after publishers criticized the original terms.
articles.abstract: Apple changed its guidelines for content subscriptions sold through its App Store after publishers criticized the original terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the tug of war between Apple and publishers over digital media, the balance of power shifted a bit this week to the side of the publishers.
